items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels have receded overnight on the Upper River Derwent and Stonethwaite Beck, though the level of Derwent Water remains high following the heavy rainfall on Saturday. There is likely to be a similar response to further rainfall through this morning (Sunday 13/02/22). Areas most at risk include the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We do not expect to be issuing Flood Warnings and  no property flooding is expected. We will continue to monitor the forecast and amend this message if necessary. Our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Monday morning (14/02/2022), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels have receded overnight following the heavy rainfall yesterday on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck but may rise again in a similar response to rainfall throughout this morning (Sunday 13/02/2022). Flooding is forecast to affect locations near these watercourses, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. We do not expect to be issuing any Flood Warnings and property flooding is not expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages and clearing debris screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, Monday 14/02/22, or as the situation changes.
This flood alert has been removed as conditions have eased and tides have fallen below a level of concern. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
